Award.AwardTitle: EXTREEMS-QED: Data-Enabled Science and Computational Analysis Research, Training and Education for Students (DESCARTES) Program
Award.AbstractNarration:
The overarching goal of this program is to provide Applied Mathematical Sciences majors at University of California, Merced (UC Merced) an enhanced academic experience that provides training in the computational tools needed for modeling and simulation of complex systems and for analysis of large data sets. The Data Enabled Science and Computational Analysis Research, Training, and Education for Students (DESCARTES) Program has three specific aims:

1. To provide exceptional undergraduate students unique research opportunities and state-of-the-art education and training in computational and data enabled science and to disseminate results from their efforts within the university and to the community at-large;

2. To develop the Computational and Data Enabled Science emphasis track within the Applied Mathematical Sciences major to provide students a hands-on learning experience on the latest tools and methods in computational and data enabled science;

3. To provide high school math teachers from the region the opportunity to learn the tools and methods of computational and data enabled science.


The UC Merced community is committed to serving the population of the San Joaquin Valley -- the fastest growing yet economically underserved region of California. Indeed, many of our students are members of underrepresented populations and most are first-generation college-goers. These students, as well as regional high school teachers, will realize significant benefits from the DESCARTES Scholars program. Both will gain access to emerging areas of research in computational and data-enabled science and the training necessary to address the complex problems confronting society today. Regional businesses and industry will benefit by forging connections to a well-trained pool of prospective employees. At the same time, the University community will take an important step towards its mission of service to the region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Data-Enabled Science and Computational Analysis Research, Training and Education for Students (DESCARTES) Program Scholars Program was a research, training, and education program for undergraduate applied math majors. DESCARTES Scholars engaged in summer workshops that supplemented their courses and summer research projects. Applied Mathematics graduate students served as mentors for the DESCARTES Scholars and led these workshops and research projects. Additionally, the DESCARTES Scholars Program hosted high school teachers in the region to the opportunity to learn the tools and methods of computational and data enabled science. Outcomes from this project were many and far-reaching.

The undergraduate DESCARTES Scholars gained valuable skills, training, and research experience that enhanced their overall undergraduate experience. Additionally, they were exposed throughout the entire time as DESCARTES Scholars to graduate school and professional career opportunities. Nearly all DESCARTES Scholars participated in REU?s across the nation and/or professional internships. The culmination of these experiences led to very high graduation rates among participants and impressively broad set of post-graduation paths including graduate school, government labs, industry, and politics. Many of the DESCARTES Scholars have explicitly credited their experiences in this project as an important factor in their post-graduation successes.

Applied Mathematics graduate students serving as mentors to the DESCARTES Scholars gained valuable experience in leading research and mentoring students. All graduate student mentors reported positive experiences. The two who have gone onto academic careers were told that their mentoring experience for the DESCARTES Scholars Program was an important factor in their selection by the hiring committees.

The high school teachers involved in the Summer Teacher Workshops have had a uniformly positive experience engaging with the campus community. Their experience allowed them to speak enthusiastically about their personal experiences to their students. We have been able to host several high school students interested in studying Applied Mathematics at UC Merced as a direct consequence. As a result of this professional development program in the project, the Merced Math Teachers Circle has emerged as an on-going effort to maintain a community of professors, students, and teachers from the region that meets regularly for fun and interactive problem-solving sessions. At the end of the day each day, participants reflect on the day?s activities and what they had learned.

An important outcome of this project is the development of the Computational and Data Sciences emphasis track in the Applied Mathematics major at UC Merced. This emphasis track has become very popular with students. The successes of the DESCARTES Scholars played an important role in promoting this emphasis track. The Applied Mathematics Department is committed to its success. The Applied Mathematics Department is also building new initiatives on the successes of the DESCARTES Scholars Program. A key result we have found in this project is that our students thrive when they are engaged as part of a community. Consequently, we are expanding on the DESCARTES principles of community learning, mentorship, preparation in all of our training activities.
